newsitem.title: USA: Texas snowstorm may hurt freeze-damaged wheat - WSC.
newsitem.headline: Texas snowstorm may hurt freeze-damaged wheat - WSC.

text.p: Forecasters now expect nearly a foot of snow in the Texas Panhandle from a major snowstorm now centered over the area, which could further damage wheat hurt by last week's freezing weather, said Joel Burgo, Weather Services Corp meteorologist.
"This would be bad for the (freeze-damaged) wheat," he said. "The snow on that wheat will cause lodging of the crop. This is not good."

Burgio said the National Weather Service late Friday morning issued a heavy snow warning for the southwest Texas Panhandle, with six to 12 inches forecast for western areas and four to six inches in eastern areas.
The hardest hit counties were Deaf Smith, Oldham, Potter and Randall. Surrounding areas should receive one to three inches, Burgio said.

Because temperatures were near freezing much of the snow was melting as it hit the ground, said Burgio. Although up to a foot of snow was forecast, the melting action should restrict accumulations to four to six inches by day's end.
Temperatures should stay near 32 degrees Fahrenheit Friday, edging into the mid-30s Saturday morning, Burgio said.
A gradual warming trend should melt the snow by Monday, said Burgio. Temperatures should gradually rise, reaching the low 40s Sunday and continue rising Monday.
